statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: USC 78, Oregon State 68
article.story: LOS ANGELES (AP) -- Errick Craven finished an otherwise tumultuous Trojan season with the best game of his college career. Craven, one of six seniors playing in their final game for USC, had a career-high 30 points in the Trojans' 78-68 win over Oregon State on Saturday night. "I was just relaxed," said Craven, who was 12-for-19 from the floor, including 4-for-5 from 3-point range. "I mean I've never seen a shot I didn't like, but I was confident. Every shot I took I thought it was going in." Craven surpassed his previous best of 29 points, scored against Washington State in 2001, his freshman season. Jeff McMillan, another Trojan senior, added 20 points and 12 rebounds, keying a USC dominance inside that resulted in a 51-35 rebounding advantage and a 28-4 edge in second-chance points. Oregon State (16-13, 8-10) was led by David Lucas' 21 points, while Nick DeWitz added 15. The Beavers, who by tip-off were already locked into the No. 5 seed for next week's Pac-10 Tournament in Los Angeles, finished the regular season with their highest win total since winning 22 games in 1989-90, but also finished with an 0-9 road record in conference play. USC did not qualify for the Pac-10 tournament for the first time in the eight seasons it has been held. The Trojans finish a season in which head coach Henry Bibby was fired four games into his ninth season at the school on Dec. 6, then saw Bibby's replacement, former Utah coach Rick Majerus, resign from the same post five days after accepting what he called his "dream job." On Jan. 14, USC hired former Iowa State and Chicago Bulls coach Tim Floyd to take over the program next season while keeping this year's team under the direction of interim coach Jim Saia. The Trojans had a 10-15 record under Saia. "It's a good way to finish it out," Saia said of the win. "This team has been through a lot this year, and I'm happy they got a win. For me, it's been a learning season, and I think I've become a better coach." USC never led in the first half but finished with a 17-6 run to tie the game at 34 at the break. The Trojans then went on a 22-10 scoring spurt over the first eight minutes of the second half to take control. Oregon State closed to within four, 59-55, on Chris Stephens' four-point play with 8:58 left, but the Trojans answered with an 11-3 run to regain a double-digit lead that they kept for the remainder of the game.
